entry.title: Preparing for SAP C_CPE? Here‚Äôs How I‚Äôm Studying Each Section Without Feeling Overwhelmed
entry.content:
Whenever I start learning something new, I like to have everything in order.
Before I even open the first tutorial, I plan what I‚Äôll study first, what comes next, and how I‚Äôll track it.

Recently, I started preparing for the SAP C_CPE (SAP Certified Associate - Backend Developer - SAP Cloud Application Programming Model) certification. Since this exam covers a mix of BTP architecture, SAP BAS, CAP, Side by side extensions, Cloud Foundry & Kyma Runtime  it can easily feel like too much at once. So I created a simple structure to move step by step without feeling lost.

I began with the learning about BTP, and doing hands on by following SAP Learning Journeys, creating subaccount and adding entitlements and services (It gave me a very clear understanding of BTP architecture) and then Developing appliaction using high productivity tools of SAP BAS, Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) because it‚Äôs the foundation of most topics in this certification. I‚Äôm spending around two weeks learning about CDS models, service layers and how everything connects in a CAP project. I‚Äôm following the official SAP Learning Journey https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-associate-backend-developer-sap-cloud-programming-model and doing small hands-on exercises along the way.

My next focus is Cloud Foundry. I‚Äôll spend about a week learning how to efficiently develop, run, and manage cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime.

After that, I‚Äôll move to Side by side extention on BTP.  This will cover deploying  extension and integrating the app into SAP Build Work Zone.

The next stage is Developing Appliactions in Kyma Environment. I‚Äôll take about two weeks to explore a comprehensive understanding of Kubernetes and to orchestrate the deployment of the applications in the cloud. 

Finally, I‚Äôll study Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK for about two more weeks. These are slightly advanced topics but very useful for understanding to develop and integrate Java, JavaScript, and TypeScript extension applications for SAP solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

So in short, this will be my roadmap-

Recommended Study Sequence

Here‚Äôs the order I suggest, from foundational to more advanced :

  1. Exploring SAP Business Technology Platform 5hrs (link : https://learning.sap.com/courses/exploring-sap-business-technology-platform)
    • This gives you a broad overview of the entire platform (services, architecture, what BTP is). Good for building your base understanding.
    • So start here.
  2. Develop Full‚ÄëStack Applications Using Productivity Tools in SAP Business Application Studio 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-full-stack-applications-using-productivity-tools-in-sap-business-application-studio)
    • Once you know the platform, you learn the developer tooling (BAS = Business Application Studio) which is key for CAP and full-stack apps. 
    • So this is your next step.
  3. Develop Applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime 4hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-on-sap-btp-cloud-foundry-runtime)
    • The Cloud Foundry runtime is a major runtime environment in BTP. Understanding how to build and deploy there is critical. 
  4. Build Side‚Äëby‚ÄëSide Extensions on SAP BTP 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/build-side-by-side-extensions-on-sap-btp)
    • After tooling and platform basics, you dive into extension scenarios (for example side-by-side extensions of S/4HANA using CAP). This aligns closely with CAP certification topics.
  5. Developing Applications in SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime 8hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-in-sap-btp-kyma-runtime)
    • Kyma Runtime is more advanced (Kubernetes, microservices, event-mesh) and often sits on top of foundational knowledge. 
  6. Develop Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK 11hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-advanced-extensions-with-sap-cloud-sdk)
    • This is relatively specialized/advanced (SAP Cloud SDK, perhaps custom libraries, integrations). Once you‚Äôve mastered the fundamentals above, you go here.

By the end of this plan, I‚Äôll go through a short revision period with mock questions and quick notes from my learning.

This structured approach keeps my study plan clear and prevents me from feeling overwhelmed.
I study for two to four hours a day which feels realistic, and the small milestones make it easier to stay consistent.

If you‚Äôre also preparing for C_CPE, it really helps to make your own sequence instead of jumping randomly between topics. The Learning Journeys are excellent resources, but having a personal roadmap makes a big difference.

 

I‚Äôd love to hear how others are preparing for this certification too.
What topics are you finding most challenging so far and how are you managing the learning.

entry.title: Additional quantity in warehouse task for production staging
entry.content:
Hello Experts!

Our client is using EWM for production staging. Here is the process we have designed:

- From production order we initiate material staging

- Then from the app 'Process Posting Change Item' we create the warehouse task with destination as the production supply area.

- We confirm the warehouse task upon physically moving the components.

- We consume the components using backflushing (CO11N screen)

Now the ask from our client is - to add some buffer quantity when we are staging in case the line operator needs more. It is the nature of the production that they often need some extra quantity.

Now the problem is, system does not allow us to increase quantity in WT. Also, we cannot increase the quantity in BOM as it will force us to backflush the total quantity.

 Is there a way we can add some tolerance (like always have 10% extra quantity) to the Warehouse Task? Say, the production order needs 10 units, but in WT system proposes 11 units?

If you feel this could be addressed by a different process, let me know. I am open to ideas/leading practices.

Thank you

Snigdhodeep

EWM - Goods Movement #EWM - Production Staging #EWM - Warehouse Tasks

entry.title: Re: EWM diff. analyzer: correct. of Q2 stock not triggeri...
entry.content:
Please see SAP-KBA "3608937 - Unable to enter Reason for Movement in Physical Inventory - SAP for Me" ...

Extract :
"Cause
In the EWM standard solution where postings from the Difference Analyzer are performed using movement type 711/712, the reason is hard coded as 'Inventory'. Hence there is no provision for the user to enter a custom reason for movement.

Resolution
The BAdI /SCWM/EX_ERP_GOODSMVT_EXT can be used to change the material document to be posted in ERP by providing a customer-specific movement type and Reason for Movement."

Hope this helps

Kind regards

Nic T.

entry.title: BI2025: Side-by-Side Migration
entry.content:
This is follow up on the migration topic to BI2025 from my blog: BI2025: Side-by-Side Migration vs. In-Place Update

Lets discuss what activities need to be planned to move to BI2025 if you choose side-by-side approach and also what kind of resource could be helpful to plan the migration/update.

Migrating from SAP BusinessObjects BI4.3 to BI2025 involves several strategic steps to ensure a smooth transition the newer platform. Based on resource availability and internal processes following major activities could be considered:

  1. Pre-Migration Planning
  2. Content Cleanup
  3. BIP 2025 deployment
  4. Content promotion
  5. Testing and Validation
  6. Training & Documentation

We will now take a detailed look at these activities.

1 . Pre-Migration Planning

  • Conduct a full assessment of your current BI 4.3 environment, including hardware, software, and system architecture. Consider to plan  following tasks:

1. 1 Environment Inventory

  • Task: Document the hardware and software components of your current BI 4.3 environment.
  • Details:
    • List all servers and their specifications (CPU, RAM, OS Version).
    • List all installed software middlwares and  databases, SDK-Applications.
    • Review all integration points with other systems, user authentification methods and used SSOs
    • Document network configurations, including firewalls, load balancers, and network topology.

You can use SAP BI Platform Support Tool to get overview of current used applications, number of reports, middlware and data base versions. Please refer to KBA 2407767 - SAP BI Platform Support Tool

Also Auditing reports are quite helpful to get overview of current system and content usage.

Please refer to following resources: SAP KBA 2456458 - Auditing in SAP BI Platform 4.x  and additional blogs about auditing, with sample reports:

  • Auditing Solution Update for SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform 4.3 +

Verify the compatibility of the new version with your current operating systems, databases, and SDK-application. Please check latest  PAM version KBA 1338845 - How to find Product Availability Matrix (PAM) / Supported Platforms Documentation for SAP BusinessObjects products?

Review features which are removed or deprecated in BI2025 and plan migration to alternative solutions.

  • Please see KBA 3560025 - Which products and features are removed in SAP BusinessObjects BI platform 2025.
  • 3582341 - FAQ on SAP BusinessObjects 2025 [BI 2025]
  • For deprecated features

Component

Go to solution

Blog

Lumira Discovery

SAP Analytics Cloud - Web Intelligence

Accelerate your move from SAP Lumira Designer to SAP Analytics Cloud

Crystal Reports for Enterprise

Crystal Reports - Web Intelligence

Moving from Crystal Reports for Enterprise to Crystal Reports

Analysis for OLAP

SAP Analytics Cloud

SAP-BusinessObjects Analysis Edition For Olap Alternatives

Live Office

SAP Analysis for Microsoft Office

Web Intelligence Document OData Access (4.3 SP2)

SAP BusinessObjects Live Office Alternatives

SAP BusinessObjects Mobile

Web browser on mobile devices

Web Intelligence Document eXtract (WIDX)

SAP BusinessObjects Mobile alternatives

Universe Design Tool (and .unv)

Information Design Tool (and .unx)

Unv is dead long live-unx 

Multi-source universes and associated connectivity

Data blending in Web Intelligence or at the DB level

BusinessObjects Multi source Universes Alternatives

Subversion as a bundled Version Management repository

Git or Github integration

SAP KBAs: 3581196 and 3335429 

1.2 User and License Assessment

  • Task: Evaluate the user base and current used licenses
  • Details:
    • List all active and inactive users.
    • Document the types of licenses currently in use.
    • Consider to create new licence keys for BI2025
  • KBAs:
    • 2251998 - How to generate license keys for SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence
    • 2282189 - New license keys required for 4.3/2025(and later)

Task 1.3 Backup and Recovery Assessment

  • Task: Assess the current backup and recovery procedures.
  • Details:
    • Check current backup methodology.
    • You will need a backup of Central Management Server (CMS) database & File Store, any Web Appserver configuration files, Webapps and customizations, and if SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform is on Virtual Machine, then it is advisable to take a snapshot of the machine.
    • Verify the integrity and restorability of backups.
    • Ensure that backups cover all critical data and configurations before performing update
  • KBAs:
    • 2306146 - Disaster recovery backup and restore best practices for restoring
    • 1275068 - Backup & Restore XI 3.1 / BI 4.x from one environment to another [video]

2. Content Cleanup

It would be good idea to perform some system clean up activities to reduce system foot print in CMS DB and FRS and also get rid off the obsolete or unused objects.

2.1. Obsolete Reporting Tools

  • Task: Review content used in BI4.3.
  • Details:
    • Based on analysis performed earlier define the strategy for outdated reporting tools/content (such as legacy Crystal Reports and Analysis for OLAP), decide whether to replace them with new solutions or remove them.
    • Archive obsolete content, if necessary. You can use LCM_BIAR files to create back-ups.
    • Remove or consolidate reports that are redundant or unused to streamline the migration process. Refer to SAP KBA 2464908 - SAP BI Promotion Management Best Practices [LCM]

Task 2.2 Consistency check

  • Task: Verify object consitency between the FRS and CMS database.
  • Details:
    • The inconsistencies can occur after disaster recovery, a network failure during a database write, content insert or update.
    • Run a Repository Diagnostics Scan (Reposcan) on Source (and on Target, after migration). Use both CMS and FRS: Scan & Repair options in the Source Environment.
  • KBAs and RDT Resources:
    • How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool
    • 1689163 - How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool (aka reposcan) in BI 4.x - for WINDOWS
    • 1752397 - How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool (aka reposcan) in BI 4.x - for Unix / Linux,
    • 2306600 - How to resolve "The object has a missing or invalid Submitter Object ID." inconsistency after a CMS database migration
    • 1695971 - Repository Diagnostic Tool (reposcan) shows more file inconsistencies after the repair
    • 1267338 - How to use Repository Diagnostic Tool (reposcan)

3. BIP 2025 deployment

Task 3.1: Hardware and Network Preparation

  • Task: Ensure that your infrastructure meets BI2025‚Äôs technical requirements including hardware, operating system, and networking specifications.
  • Details:
    • Consider to check BI2025 PAM to verify if all prerequisites met
    • Align on network requirements and firewalls rules requierd for new enviroment. Please refer to KBA 2276646 - Firewall considerations for BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform 4.x (Servers and Clients)

For example, in PAM you can find information on supported in BI2025 operating systems and web application servers:

 

Provider NameNameMinimum Supported versionLatest
certified version		Supported
since		Notes

 

Tomcat9.x9.xBI 2025

Certified for SAP Machine (Java 17). As free open-source third-party web application server, SAP recommends you contact a qualified third-party vendor or consultant for performance tuning, security related issues and load balancer configurations (see SAP KBA 2280098). Please check KBA 2112338 for bundled tomcat and JVM version

BI 2025 is only supported on Windows and Linux operating systems and the Solaris and AIX support is removed.
With the GA release, BI 2025 is only supported on Tomcat Application Server, more importantly SAP NetWeaver application server support is removed. And other application servers certification is planned for future.

Next important topic is also BIP Add-ons.

‚ÄãBI2025 requires new Lumira Add-on - SAP Lumira Designer 2025, which is currently planned to be released in Q12026:
 
Analysis for Office Add-On.
‚ÄãBI2025 requires at least Analysis for Office SP26 installer.
‚ÄãFurthermore, additional improvement planned for AO 2.8 SP28  related to the SNC and the OpenID usage for the BIP Logon:
  • 3631157 - AO: BIP Logon via OpenID - Implemented possibility to use embedded browser
  • 3645976 - AO: BIP - Logon User is not available when using OpenID authentication
  • 3667319 - AO scheduling issues after upgrading server add-on to 2.8.26/27

4. Content promotion

Next we will take a look on activities related to content migration.

4.1 Target System Server Configuration

  • Task: Adjust setting realted to the promotion execution.
  • Details:
  •  Required Running Services
    • Core Services (Must Run):
    • Central Management Server (CMS)
    • Input File Repository Server (FRS)
    • Output File Repository Server (FRS)
    • Adaptive Job Server (AJS) with increased heap
    • Adaptive Processing Server (APS) with LCM services
    • Crystal Reports Application Server (RAS)
    • Connection Server
  • Memory Configuration:
    • Configure Promotion Management Service APS heap size to handle large content imports - minimum 15GB for bulk migrations. Set Java heap parameters in CMC > Servers > APS Properties > Command Line Arguments: -javaargs -Xmx15g or higher 
    • Increase AJS heap size to minimum 15GB for large-scale promotions. Configure in CMC > Servers > AJS Properties > Command Line Arguments: -javaargs -Xmx15g
  • System Settings
    • Disable auditing on target system during migration
    • Disable monitoring in CMC > Monitoring Application
    • Disable Platform Search/indexing to improve performance
    • Configure adequate temporary space - minimum 2.5x FRS size
  • Turn OFF rollback on target server for large data imports to improve performance
  • Disable firewalls/antivirus temporarily during migration if possible 
  • Authentication Settings
    • Configure external authentication on target but do NOT import groups initially
    • Disable authentication temporarily during bulk user/group migration for better performance
    • Re-enable authentication after user migration completion

4.2 Promotion Tool Selection

In next step you need to decide which of two available for content promotion tools is more suitable for your landscape/team. You can select between Promotion Management Wizard (PMW) and Command Line Interface (CLI). The table below summarise the feature for these tools:

 
Feature
PMW (Promotion Management Wizard)CLI (Command Line Interface)
Tool TypeGUI-based promotion toolCommand-line based tool
User InterfaceGraphical wizard interface with step-by-step guidanceText-based commands requiring syntax knowledge
Ease of UseUser-friendly for non-technical usersRequires technical expertise and command knowledge
Automation CapabilityLimited automation, primarily manual wizard stepsHigh automation potential through scripting
Batch OperationsSupports batch promotion of multiple objectsExcellent for bulk operations and scripting
Error HandlingVisual error messages and guided troubleshootingDetailed error logs but requires interpretation
Learning CurveLow - intuitive wizard-driven processHigh - requires command syntax and parameter knowledge
SchedulingManual execution through GUICan be scheduled via system schedulers
LoggingBuilt-in logging with visual feedbackComprehensive command-line logging
Remote ExecutionRequires GUI access to serverCan be executed remotely via SSH/terminal
Scripting SupportNo native scripting capabilityFull scripting and automation support
PerformanceGood for small to medium promotionsBetter performance for large-scale operations

The choice ultimately depends on your team's technical capabilities, automation requirements, and the specific nature of your promotion scenarios. Many organizations benefit from using both tools for different use cases within their BI platform management strategy. For example, for large-scale migrations:

  1. Use PMW for initial bulk content migration (users, groups, dependencies)
  2. Switch to CLI for large content in public/favourite folders or delta promotions and ongoing maintenance
  3. Use CLI for promoting instances and objects created after initial migration

Check out the Promotion Management best practices SAP KBAs:

  • 2464908 - SAP BI Promotion Management Best Practices [LCM]
  • 1969259 - LCMCLI Best Practices - How to promote thousands of objects in BI Platform using command line?
  • KBA 2464908, 2531264 - Best Practices for Promotion Management Wizard (PMW)
  •  SAP BI Pattern Book on Promotion
  • 3663096 - How to promote object or folder security but not content using the PMW tool when performing bulk content migration?

4.3 Phased Promotion Approach

For large deployment would make sense to split whole promotion in multiple phases. Below you will find recommended sequins for such aproach.

Phase 1: Security and Users.

  • Migrate user groups and users without dependencies
  • Include user artifacts (Inboxes, Favorites Folders, Personal Categories)
  • Validate user authentication and group memberships

Phase 2: Dependencies

  • Migrate Access Levels, Applications, Business Views, Calendars, Connections
  • Migrate Universes (UNX only), Data Source References, Events

Phase 3: Content Migration

  • Migrate public folders and content
  • Use selective content promotion in chunks for large repositories
  • For bulk operations, use LCM CLI with multiple queries capability

Phase 4: Security Application (Optional)

  • Apply object security using PMW by selecting objects at folder hierarchy endpoints
  • Consider using CLI for security replication following KBA 3663096 patterns

5. Testing and Validation

  • Task: Perform technical and functional testing.
  • Details:
    • Perform compatibility test and verify the functionality of all migrated assets on the new platform to ensure they work as intended.
    • Performance Testing: Conduct load testing to evaluate the performance of the BI2025 system under typical and peak conditionsUser Acceptance Testing (UAT): Engage business users in testing to validate usability and functionality from an end-user perspective.

6. Training & Documentation

  • Task: Consider to organize the trainings for end users and update the documentation
  • Details:
    • User Training: Provide comprehensive training sessions for users to acquaint them with new features and interfaces in BI2025.
    • Updated Documentation: Create and distribute updated documentation reflecting changes and new functionalities in the BI2025 environment.

I tried to provide some initial guides for migration to BI2025. The tasks can vary based on landscape complexity and available resource but general approach stays the same. 

Please also consider to check SAP Premium Engagement: A service roadmap for SAC, S/4 Embedded Analytics, Business Objects and Planning  for some details on SAP‚Äôs Center of Expertise (COE) for Analytics, Planning, and Consolidation and how we helping around analytic topics.

entry.title: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

ABAP Proxies are one of the most widely used integration technologies in SAP landscapes. For years, they have been central to PI/PO-based integrations. Now, with the availability of ABAP Proxy support in SAP Integration Suite, customers can extend this capability to the cloud, accelerating their migration from PI/PO to Integration Suite. This closes an important gap for organizations transitioning from SAP Process Integration (PI/PO) to SAP Integration Suite .

This blog provides a technical overview and step-by-step setup guide for enabling generation of ABAP Proxies with Integration Suite.

What Are ABAP Proxies?

  • ABAP Proxies are generated classes in the SAP ABAP system based on service interfaces defined in the Enterprise Service Repository (ESR).

  • They allow ABAP developers to call or expose services without dealing with low-level communication protocols.

  • Proxies are commonly used for synchronous/asynchronous service calls, typically via SOAP adapters in PI/PO.

Why ABAP Proxy Support in SAP Integration Suite Matters?

Until recently, ABAP proxies were heavily tied to on-premise PI/PO middleware. With many customers moving their integration  to the cloud, there was a strong demand for equivalent support in Integration Suite.

Key benefits of the new support include:

  • Cloud-first Enablement ‚Äì Seamlessly connect SAP backends to Integration Suite using proxies.
  • Reuse of Existing Investments ‚Äì No need to redesign all integration scenarios; existing service interfaces can still be leveraged.
  • Simplified Migration from PI/PO ‚Äì Reduces the complexity of moving from legacy middleware to cloud-based integration.
  • Standardized Integration ‚Äì Continue using ESR artifacts and ABAP proxies as standardized communication interfaces.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Integration Suite tenant is active.
  • Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite (HTTPS) is enabled.
  • Certificates (for mutual TLS if required) are exchanged.
  • Service interface meant for proxy generation must already be present/imported inside an Integration Package of the  SAP Integration Suite tenant
  • You've a user with the role  AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned.

Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite

For ABAP Proxy to Integration Suite, the standard practice is to configure an SM59 destination of type G.

SM59 Destination Configuration (Type G) :

Configuration Steps in SM59 (Type G)

Go to Transaction SM59

Choose HTTP Connections to External Server.

Create a new destination  or Open the existing Destination with name SAP_PROXY_ESR 

Technical Settings

  • Target Host: The host name of Integration Suite tenant(Navigate to BTP Cockpit  Instances and Subscriptions  < your instance for Service Process Integration Runtime with api Plan> View Credentials (in JSON format) and copy the url(without https://)  Note : Do not use the clientId and client secret from the Service Key instance

  • Service No.: 443 (for HTTPS).
  • Path Prefix: Enter the following : /rest/api/v1/workspace/sproxy 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Logon & Security

  • Choose Basic Authentication
  • Enter the credentials of the Technical user  with role AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned and created with Default Identity Provider
  • Security Options
    • Select SSL Active
    • Import CPI‚Äôs Server certificate into transaction STRUST (SSL Client ‚Üí Standard).
    • Assign it to the relevant SSL Client PSE so that HTTPS trust is established

  • Save the changes and Perform Connection Test. Successful Connection Test result in HTTP 200 Ok Response .

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedure to Generate ABAP Proxy

  • Log into the SAP ABAP backend system (ECC or S/4HANA).
  • Run transaction SPROXY.
    • This transaction allows browsing and generating proxies from  Service Interfaces present in the Integration Suite tenant that is configured in SM59 destination(SAP_PROXY_ESR)
    • In the Enterprise Service Browser view, navigate to Source --> ESR --> SWCs  to see the list of Integration Packages that contain atleast one of the proxy relevant artifacts(Datatypes,(Fault)Message Types,Service Interfaces) are listed.
    • Locate the Integration Package containing the desired Service Interface (Inbound or Outbound).
    • Drill down to Service Provider or Service Consumer.(Namespaces -->Choose the desire namespace -->Object Types)
    • Choose the Inbound (server proxy) or Outbound (client proxy) interface.
    • Right-click the selected Service Provider or Consumer ‚Üí choose Generate.
    • Proxy Generation Wizard opens. Provide:
    • Prefix for ABAP Class Names (if needed).
    • Package assignment (should be a transportable package, not $TMP if moving to QA/Prod).
    • Transport request for recording the generated objects.
    • The system creates ABAP proxy classes:
      • Inbound Server Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class implementing the interface with predefined methods (developer writes business logic here).
      • Outbound Client Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class to call external services (system generates methods to call the remote service).
      • Supporting DDIC structures, types, and message interfaces are also generated.
      • Save and Activate the generated proxies

Use the  generated proxy class to implement the Business logic  in Transaction SE80 or SE24 .

Current Limitations in the SPROXY Navigation Tree :

  • Folders are not visible in the SPROXY navigation tree
  • Datatype enhancements are not listed.
  • Classifications and Matching Service Interface details will be missing in the Proxy Editor of the Service Interface
  • ...

Recommended view to be used - Enterprise Services Browser view.

Also please ensure to import the service interfaces and its dependants to the Integration Suite tenant from the PI/PO ESR system that was earlier configured in SM 59 destination to be able to retain the already generated proxies. Try maintaining SWCV  to Integration Package mapping i.e. Avoid importing objects from multiple SWCV's to one Integration Packages.. Avoid having objects with same name and namespace in multiple Integration Packages.

entry.title: Re: Error 7000 while installing Integration services (B1if)
entry.content:
I reinstalled mine from the package B1IF10P_19-20009683.ZIP from SAP Download Center. I also found when searching the notes the following from SAP AI: 

Generated Answer
When installing the SAP Business One Integration Framework (B1if), issues may arise such as the installation rolling back without any errors or logs, particularly on Windows Server 2019 or 2022. To address this, it is recommended to manually install VC++ 2010 (x86/x64) before proceeding with the B1if installation. If the installation wizard closes unexpectedly during the process, reinstalling the B1if may resolve the issue. SAP plans to release feature packages or patches to address these problems, which will be available based on their discretion and the complexity of the implementation.
 
This helped my installation by installing the VC++2010 x64 for my Windows 2022 server, and it went through. Hope that helps.

entry.title: CAP Calling a Function Module (RFC) in Node.js using @sap/cds-rfc
entry.content:
Hello everyone in the community,
I‚Äôve recently started working with SAP CAP and BTP, and I was assigned a task CAP Calling a Function Module (RFC) in Node.js using the npm package @SAP/cds-rfc (https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/cds-rfc). There is a small issue when I'm trying to install this package is that the modules uses package @SAP-rfc/node-rfc-library - which is not available on the standard npmjs.com registry.

So I followed all the steps from this guide: https://qiita.com/tami/items/3b84e5cd7f789c5af7ef. I‚Äôve obtained the NPM64 credentials token using my S-User account and added it along with "@SAP-rfc:registry=https://73554900100900009091.npmsrv.repositories.cloud.sap //73554900100900009091.npmsrv.repositories.cloud.sap/.." to the .npmrc file, but every time I try to install the package, it throws a 403 Unauthorized error.
I‚Äôm not sure if I missed something along the way.
Thank you so much for your time, and I really appreciate any help or advice from the community! ‚ù§Ô∏è

entry.title: What does "APF Buffers Found in Cache" (in sp_sysmon) mean?
entry.content:
In the sp_sysmon Asynchronous Prefetch Activity Report doc page it says:

"APF Buffers Found in Cache ‚Äì reports the number buffers from APF look-ahead sets that were found in the data cache during the sample interval. Asynchronous prefetch tries to find a page to read in the data cache using a quick scan, without holding the cache spinlock. If that does not succeed, APF then performs a thorough scan holding the spinlock"

What is an "APF look-ahead set"?

Is this saying the APF process will fetch some pages of data then check if they're already in the main cache?

If so, then if the "APF Buffers Found in Cache" number is high, does it mean the APF performed useless work?  (ie., fetched pages that were already cached?)

Stated another way, who does the "found" refer to?   Does "found" refer to APF process finding the buffers already in the main data cache? (bad)   Or does "found" refer to a user process finding the pages in the data cache as a result of the APF?  (good)

Thanks in advance
Ben

entry.title: Re: Extend Custom Purchase Order API Custom Fields to Sto...
entry.content:
Good day @Rawel 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some references to guide you.

API_PURCHASEORDER_2, Operations for Purchase Order, Stock Transfer Using Stock Transport Order,

SAP KBA 3110493

Based on your description, it seems the API cannot recognise your extension field in the STO context.

To summarise, in public cloud, updating custom fields on Purchase Orders works only for standard order types (e.g., NB) through API_PURCHASORDER_PROCESS_SRV. For Stock Transport Orders (type UB), the system uses a different API (API_STOCKTRANSORDER_PROCESS_SRV), which currently does not support custom fields extensions.

That means, when you send custom field values in your update payload, the system returns 422 unprocessable entity because those fields are not recognised in the STO data model. You can workaround this while adhering to the clean-core compliance and preventing integration failure by:

  • Skipping custom field updates for UB types in your integration logic
  • Maintaining STO-related extension data in a side table or CBO and link it to the PO number

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Forms Service by Adobe Technical Configuration Overview
entry.content:
In modern SAP landscapes, generating consistent, branded, and compliant business documents across heterogeneous environments is a recurring requirement. SAP Forms Service by Adobe (ADS) enables the dynamic rendering of print and interactive PDF forms, providing a unified document generation capability across SAP S/4HANA, SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and on-premise systems. This blog provides a technical overview and configuration guide for connecting SAP Forms Service by Adobe on BTP and S/4HANA RISE PCE.

 

1. Architecture Overview

The SAP Forms Service by Adobe (ADS) can be consumed under several deployment models depending on your landscape. The integration is defined by how the ABAP system communicates with the ADS instance running in BTP.

1.1 Cloud Applications (via REST API)
Cloud-native applications can directly call the SAP Forms REST API to render forms dynamically using service configuration UIs. 

 

1.2 ABAP Applications on BTP
ABAP apps running in the BTP ABAP environment can call the service through standard integration methods.

1.3 S/4HANA On-Premise Systems

On-premise systems connect to the service through SAP Cloud Connector, which enables secure communication between the backend and the BTP-based forms service.

 

2. Restrictions

Type

Max File Size (per File)

Font file

25 MB

Customer XDC/XCI files

2 MB

Job profiles

1 MB

Credential/certificates/CRLs

5 MB

Data migration (.zip)

150 MB

Type

Max Storage Size (Total Volume)

Fonts

150 MB

XDC/XCI

20 MB

Job profiles

5 MB

Type

Max. Size

Storage size for error PDFs

10 MB

Size for destination cache

15 MB

Form template size for rendering

data size for attaching to PDF

20 MB

Input PDF size for PDF operations

10 MB

SAP Forms Service Support Fonts

  • OpenType¬Æ (.otf)
  • TrueType¬Æ (.ttf)
  • PostScript¬Æ Type 1 (.pfb)

Supported Versions

  • S/4HANA: 1809 SP8+, 1909 SP6+, 2020 SP4+, 2021 or higher
  • NetWeaver: 7.50 SP24 or higher
  • ABAP Environment on SAP BTP

 

3. Prerequisites and Setup

3.1 Configuring BTP

  • Create a Subaccount
  • Subscribe to the SAP Forms Service
  • Create a REST API Instance
  • Create a Service Instance for ABAP or On-Premise Integration
  • Assign Roles

Refer to this for more details: Initial Steps in Your SAP BTP Subaccount

3.2 Configuring ADS in S/4 HANA On-Premise

  • User Management - Transaction SU01
  • RFC Destination Setup - Transaction SM59
  •  CF Service Activation -Transaction SICF

Refer to this for more details: Connecting the SAP Forms Service to ABAP

 

Conclusion

The SAP Forms Service by Adobe (ADS) forms a critical component in modern SAP system architectures where hybrid or fully cloud-based landscapes require centralized document rendering. Unlike traditional on-premise ADS setups embedded in Java stacks, the BTP-hosted ADS model decouples rendering logic from the application layer, offering better scalability, resilience, and version control across environments.

From a technical standpoint, correct configuration of RFC destinations, ICF nodes, and SAP Cloud Connector mappings is essential for ensuring stable communication between S/4HANA (on-premise or RISE PCE) and the BTP ADS service. System administrators should also validate SSL certificates, maintain trusted connections to BTP subaccounts, and regularly test the ADS endpoint availability using standard reports.

 

SAP Forms service by Adobe

entry.title: Sorting and aggregation in the SAP Adobe form using scripting language
entry.content:
Requirement:
Display only one record per invoice number, even if the invoice contains multiple items. The displayed record should show the total (summed) amount of all items belonging to that invoice.

Assumption:
The internal table containing the invoice data is already extracted and correctly bound to the form context, ensuring that the data is displayed accurately in the output.

Scenario:
To illustrate this case, we are using sample data from the invoice item table (DFKKINVDOC_I), which stores all item-level details for each invoice number.



Now, let's try to generate the PDF and see the output.

Observe that some of the invoice numbers are already sorted but some are not and hence we need to sort the records according to the invoice number. Sorting and aggregation are two steps, hence we will see one by one each step to fulfill the requirements.

Solution:

Sorting and aggregation can easily be achieved using ABAP code in on-premise systems. However, since we are working in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, we need to perform these operations using a scripting language.
In this case, we‚Äôll use JavaScript within the Adobe Form.

Step 1:- Sorting the records first will help us perform the aggregation correctly later.

  • Select the Table in the form layout.

  • Go to the Events tab.

  • Choose the form:ready event.

  • Set the Language to JavaScript.

Step 2:- Write the JavaScript Code for Sorting

Now, write the JavaScript code inside the form:ready event to sort the table records based on the invoice number.

var count = xfa.resolveNodes("GT_INVOICE.DATA[*]").length; // Get the number of records in the table
var table = this.DATA; // Access the Data node of the table
var i = 0; // Iteration for the outer loop
var j = 0; // Iteration for the inner loop
var intialInvoice; // Initial invoice number for which we need to find the duplicate invoice
var duplicateInvoice; // Duplicate invoice number corresponding to the initial invoice

for ( i = 0; i <= count - 1; i++ ){
      intialInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
      for ( j = i + 1; j <= count - 1; j++ ){
             duplicateInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ j +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
            // if the invoice number is greater, then move the instance( replace the instance of ith index and jth index)
                if ( intialInvoice > duplicateInvoice ) {
                      table.instanceManager.moveInstance(j, i);
                      }
               }
        }

Step 3:- Test the Sorting

Generate the PDF and verify if the data is now sorted by invoice number.

You should observe that the invoice numbers are displayed in sorted order.

Step 4:- Aggregate the Amounts for Each Invoice

The next step is to aggregate the total amount for each invoice.

In the same form:ready event of the GT_INVOICE, add the JavaScript code that compares invoice numbers and sums up the amounts for matching records.
Since the data is already sorted, the loop can safely exit once a non-matching invoice number is found, improving performance.

 

Generate the PDF again and verify that the aggregation works as expected.

You should now see the aggregated amount displayed for each invoice number (refer to the previous screenshot of sorted data for comparison).
The total amount for each invoice appears in the Amount field of the first record for that invoice ‚Äî this happens because our JavaScript logic updates only the first instance.

Step 5:- Display Only One Record per Invoice

Although the aggregation is correct, multiple line items of the same invoice are still visible.
We now need to hide the duplicate invoice entries and display only one record per invoice ‚Äî the one containing the aggregated value.

To achieve this, enhance the JavaScript code in the same form:ready event to suppress duplicate invoice records.
Below is the updated JavaScript code snippet that performs both aggregation and duplicate removal.

 

i = 0;   // reset the value of i to 0
j = 0;   // reset the value of j to 0
var previousInvoice;
var sum = 0;
 
 for ( i = 0; i <= count - 1; i++ ){ 
       initialInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue; 
      // initially the previousInvoice is empty and hence we need to put 
      // the invoice number of first iteration of for loop
      if ( previousInvoice == null || previousInvoice == "Empty" || previousInvoice == " "  ){
            previousInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
       }
      
      if ( ( previousInvoice != null ) && ( previousInvoice == initialInvoice ) ){
                   
          // catch the first iteration of an invoice number from the sorted list
          // counting the number of matching records because we need to hide the other duplicate values
          // only the first iteration of any invoice needs to be retained
          if ( countIteration == '0' ){
               indexValue = i;
          }
          else {
             xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").presence = "hidden";
          }
          countIteration = countIteration + 1;
          
       // add the amounts of matching invoice numbers
       sum = sum + xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").BETRW.rawValue;
      }
      else if( ( previousInvoice != null ) && ( previousInvoice != initialInvoice ) ){
           // here the new invoice number is found and hence the previousInvoice needs to be changed
           // also the sum of amount of earlier invoice number should be updated
           
           xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ indexValue +"]").BETRW.rawValue = sum;
           
           // now reset the value of sum, indexValue and countIteration
           sum = 0;
           indexValue = 0;
           countIteration = 0;
           
           previousInvoice = xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ i +"]").INVDOCNO.rawValue;
           
           // Capture the first iteration of the new invoice number
           indexValue = i;
           // Do the sum of the new invoice number
           sum = sum + xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ indexValue +"]").BETRW.rawValue;
           // increase the iteration counter since the first iteration index has already been captured
           countIteration = countIteration + 1;
           
      }
        
      // check the last iteration of the loop
      // last record should be considered separately
       if ( i == count - 1 ) {
            xfa.resolveNode("GT_INVOICE.DATA["+ indexValue +"]").BETRW.rawValue = sum;
       }
   }

Step 6: Test the Final Output

Generate the PDF once again and verify the output.
You should now see only one record per invoice, each displaying the aggregated amount value.

Please find the attached Javascript code in the text file below for the reference.

Final Result 

The data is now sorted correctly based on the invoice number and also we see only one record of each item with the aggregated amount is being displayed.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions or any other solution for such requirements.

 

Thanks,
Shubham

entry.title: Step-by-step guide: Attaching documents to a Bill of Materials and making them visible in Production
entry.content:
Bill of Materials is a master data which we use to maintain the components of the end product. For example, in order to produce a bicycle, we require saddle, handlebar assembly, chain and others. Taking this as example, for some cases, a drawing document of the bicycle may be included as BoM. In manufacturing environments, it‚Äôs common to have technical documents such as drawings, specifications, or quality instructions that need to be accessible during production. 

SAP Document Management System (DMS) allows us to link such documents directly to the Bill of Materials (BOM), ensuring they‚Äôre visible in production or process orders under Document Link section.

This blog explains step by step how to attach a document in a BOM and automatically display it in the production order.

First step: To create Attachment/ Document (SAT type) via Create Document: Initial Screen (CV01N)

Prerequisite: Document type must be linked with PORDER object in SPRO.

Configuration Path:

 SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí Document Management ‚Üí Control Data ‚Üí Define Document Type ‚Üí (Select Document Type) ‚Üí Define Object Links.

For example, here I used SAT document type.

 

Second step: To set the document to Release(H3) in Document Data Tab via CV01N/CV02N

Prerequisite: Original must be stored.

For the context, the Original above refers to the source document or the primary file that can be in any type such as PDF, word, text file, etc and is stored in document info record. 

Now, back to the prerequisite steps as following.
1) In the Change Document screen, click on Originals tab and check if the original has been stored.
2) The, click on activate button to ativate the original.

Next, go to the tab Document Data and change the Document Status to H3 (Released).

Third step: To attach the Document in the BOM (CS01/CS02)
Open transaction CS01 (Create BOM) or CS02 (Change BOM) and then navigate to General -> Item.

On the Change material BOM:Item:General Data screen, follow the steps as below:

  • Set Item Category = D (Document), then press Enter.
  • Assign the required Document Number, Document Type, and Document Part/Version if applicable.

After assigning, the attached document will appear in the Document tab. Double click on the Document, it will open the Document page where we can view the attachment.

Go to Original tab to see attachment. Click on attachment to view.

Fourth step: To check the changes in BOM and update them in C223 for production version.

Fifth Step: To create Production/Process Order manually (CO01)
Then, on the screen Production order Create: Header, go to Documents tab

On the screen Production Order Create: Document Links, click on Bill of Material tab.


After clicking the Bill of Material tab, the attached document is automatically assigned in the production order.


In conclusion, in order to have the document attachment to be passed to production order, a combination of DMS and BoM need to be done.  It will make it easier for the users to review or check the documents if we link it directly to production order under Document Link section rather than to have to check the BoM. Other than that, these procedures surely will enhance transparency and improve manufacturing execution efficiency.

entry.title: Project Manager Only WBS Changes via custom CDS Views and Enterprise Project Validation BAdI
entry.content:
Introduction:

This guide shows how to enforce a validation in S/4HANA Public Cloud so that only the project manager of a project can change its WBS elements. We will combine Custom CDS Views to derive the project manager and the Enterprise Project Cloud BAdI to implement the validation at runtime.

Standard behaviour:

In the standard Project Control ‚Äì Enterprise Projects app (F3215), any user with the role SAP_BR_PROJ_FIN_CONTROLLER or assigned the roles like Project FIN Controller or project manager can modify projects and project elements; there is no built-in check to restrict changes to only assigned roles like project manager.

SAP provides several released CDS views for enterprise projects, such as:

  • I_EnterpriseProject
  • I_EnterpriseProjectTeamMember
  • I_EntProjectEntitlement
  • I_EnterpriseProjectRole

However, none of these exposes the project manager directly, so we will build a custom CDS view to identify who the project manager is per project.

Prerequisites:

You need the following business roles to develop and test this solution:

 Business Role

Business Role ID

Extensibility Specialist

SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC

Project Financial Controller

SAP_BR_PROJ_FIN_CONTROLLER

 

If you do not have these roles, ask your administrator to assign them, or, if you are the administrator, follow the  Maintain Business Users guide.

For debugging Cloud BAdIs, you may also need:

Business Role

Business Role ID

Application Support Engineer - Development Support

SAP_BR_APPL_SUP_ENG_DEV_SUP

Application Support Engineer

SAP_BR_APPL_SUPPORT_ENGINEER

For general background on BAdI debugging, see the blog  Generate Customer Project Id via BAdI Project Determination (/S4PPM/PROJECT_DETERMINATION_2).

Development Overview:

  1. Create a custom CDS view that joins project entitlements with team members and roles to expose the project manager.
  2. Create a project manager view that resolves the business user.
  3. Implement the Enterprise Project validation BAdI to block changes to WBS elements by non‚Äìproject managers.

Step 1 Create Custom CDS view that joins project entitlements with team members and roles

Open the APP: Custom CDS Views (Fiori ID: F1866A)

  • Name: YY1_ProjectTeamEntitlement
  • Scenario: Standard CDS view
  • Primary Data Source: I_EntProjectEntitlement

Add Associated Data Source:  I_EnterpriseProjectTeamMember, I_EnterpriseProjectRole, I_EnterpriseProject.

 

The overview data source is as follows: 

Notes:

- I_EntProjectEntitlement is required; without it, the link between the team member and the role will be missing.

- When joining I_EntProjectEntitlement and I_EnterpriseProjectTeamMember, include both ProjectUUID and TeamMemberUUID in the join.

- Include Role Category to filter for the project manager for the next step.

- Include BusinessPartnerUUID to retrieve project manager details.

 

 

Step2: Create the Project Manager view:

  • Name: YY1_ProjectManager
  • Scenario: Standard CDS view
  • Primary Data Source: YY1_ProjectTeamEntitlement

Add Associated Data Source:  I_BusinessUserBasic.

Define filters so that only project managers are returned:

 

You can preview the data to verify that the correct project manager information is exposed per project:

Step3: Implement Enterprise Project Validation BADI

Open APP: Custom Logic (Fiori ID: F6957)

Create Custom Logic implementation with:

  • Business Context: Project Element
  • Select ID: /S4PPM/PROJ_ELMNT_VALIDATION

 

* Example code for Project Manager validation

  DATA(current_user) = cl_abap_context_info=>get_user_technical_name( ).

  SELECT SINGLE * FROM YY1_ProjectManager WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS

     WHERE projectuuid = @enterpriseprojectelement-projectuuid

*       AND userID = @Current_User

      INTO @DATA(l_ProjectManager).

  IF l_ProjectManager-userId <> current_user.

      APPEND INITIAL LINE TO validationmessages ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_validationmessage>).

      <ls_validationmessage>-systemmessageclass     = '/S4PPM/VAL_DET'.

      <ls_validationmessage>-systemmessagetype    = 'E'.

      <ls_validationmessage>-systemmessagenumber  = '000'.

      <ls_validationmessage>-systemmessagevariable1 = 'WBS can only changed by Project Manager'.

  ENDIF.

 

This logic fetches the current technical user, looks up the project‚Äôs manager from YY1_ProjectManager, and raises an error if the current user is not the project manager.

 

Conclusion

This walkthrough demonstrates how to restrict WBS element changes to the assigned project manager in S/4HANA Public Cloud. By deriving the project manager through custom CDS views and enforcing the rule via the Enterprise Project validation BAdI, you can add a targeted control that is not available in standard functionality.

entry.title: Re: Import Supplier Invoice template - XREF1 and XREF2 no...
entry.content:
Hi @miazafirah ,

The public cloud version is based on a ‚Äúwhitelisted API‚Äù concept. Only fields released by SAP for business extensibility are available in templates and OData services.
XREF1 and XREF2 are considered technical reference fields in FI documents and are not yet released for business use in the supplier invoice upload interface.

Option 1 ‚Äì Use Custom Fields & Logic (Recommended)
‚Ä¢ Go to App: Custom Fields and Logic.
‚Ä¢ Business Context: Supplier Invoice Header or Supplier Invoice Item.
‚Ä¢ Add fields (e.g., ‚ÄúReference Key 1‚Äù, ‚ÄúReference Key 2‚Äù).
‚Ä¢ Mark available in UI, OData, and Excel Template.
‚Ä¢ Publish ‚Üí Fields appear in upload template and Create Invoice app.

Option 2 ‚Äì Extend API / Communication Scenario
‚Ä¢ Extend SAP_COM_0057 with custom fields created above.
‚Ä¢ Regenerate communication arrangement.
‚Ä¢ Use extended fields in integration interface (API or upload).

Option 3 ‚Äì Use Journal Entry Upload App
‚Ä¢ If your requirement is purely FI posting with XREF1/XREF2 values (not MM invoices), use App: Import General Journal Entries.
‚Ä¢ This app supports XREF1 and XREF2 fields directly.

Option 4 ‚Äì Submit SAP Influence Request
‚Ä¢ Request SAP to expose XREF1/XREF2 in Supplier Invoice Import API/template.
‚Ä¢ Submit via Customer Influence Portal for S/4HANA Cloud.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: When the PO (purchase order) amount is lower than the...
entry.content:
HI @easap ,

Follow below steps.

-Create PO for 9 (ME21N).
-Goods Receipt for PO = 9 (MIGO). ‚Üí posts GR/IR liability for 9.
-Vendor posts invoice for 10 against the PO (MIRO). ‚Üí system posts invoice price variance (if allowed) or blocks the invoice if variance tolerance exceeded.
-Vendor issues credit note for 1; you post the vendor credit memo referencing the PO / invoice (MIRO ‚Äî ‚ÄúCredit memo‚Äù) or you post a reversing invoice.
-System clears GR/IR and vendor open items so net payable = 9 and inventory/expense value = 9 (depending on configuration).

entry.title: Re: Any differences in functionality in Finance between S...
entry.content:
HI @Susana1 ,

Here‚Äôs a clean tabular comparison between SAP S/4HANA 2023 On-Premise and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, focused on Finance (FI/GL/CO) functionality and related aspects.

 

AreaS/4HANA 2023 On-PremiseS/4HANA Cloud Private EditionRemarks
Core Finance (FI/GL)Fully available with complete configuration flexibility.Fully available with same functional scope.Both share the same code line for Finance.
COPA / PROF_ Fields*Standard COPA functionality; custom fields and extensions possible.Includes same COPA functions, plus may receive earlier or additional enhancements.Cloud Private may receive innovations faster.
Controlling (CO)Full CO capabilities with flexible customizing.Same CO functions available, aligned with clean-core principles.Functional parity, but approach to customization differs.
Embedded Analytics / AIAvailable, but some innovations come later.Some innovations (AI, predictive accounting) available earlier or exclusively.Cloud-first innovation strategy.
Universal JournalFully supported.Fully supported.No difference.
Parallel Ledgers / Multi-GAAPSupported.Supported.Identical functionality.
Custom Fields & ExtensionsUnlimited flexibility via classic ABAP, modifications, and user exits.Allowed through extensibility framework, but with restrictions to maintain clean core.On-premise offers deeper modification options.
Integration with BTP / Cloud ServicesOptional; customer-managed.Tight integration with SAP BTP services out of the box.Cloud Private is designed for hybrid integration.
Upgrades & Release ManagementFully controlled by customer; upgrade anytime.Managed by SAP; regular release schedule with limited control over timing.On-premise allows more flexibility.
Infrastructure ResponsibilityCustomer/partner-hosted; full system control.SAP or hyperscaler-hosted; managed infrastructure.Cloud Private reduces IT operations effort.
Security & ComplianceCustomer controls all policies and patches.Managed by SAP with standardized security and compliance.Cloud Private provides stronger compliance assurance.
Add-ons / Industry SolutionsAll legacy and partner add-ons supported.Most available, but some legacy ones may not be certified for Cloud.Verify compatibility before migration.
Performance OptimizationFully under customer control.Optimized by SAP under managed infrastructure.Similar results, but control differs.
TCO / Cost ModelHigher upfront investment (CAPEX model).Subscription-based (OPEX model) with predictable costs.Cloud Private reduces infrastructure and upgrade costs.
Innovation Adoption SpeedCustomer-driven; slower adoption cycle.SAP-driven; faster access to new functionality.Cloud-first development focus.
Extension PolicyTraditional ABAP allowed.Must follow clean-core and side-by-side extensions via BTP.Different development approach required.
Typical Customer ProfileComplex landscapes, heavy customization, industry-specific needs.Customers wanting cloud benefits with on-premise-like flexibility.Decision depends on governance and control needs.


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Automated Alerts for Data Action Failures in SAC
entry.content:
Introduction

As a standard feature, SAP Analytics Cloud sends the alerts/ notification  for Data Management job failures whereas for the Data Actions  there is no such alert mechanism, and it requires manual monitoring to track the status of process.

For Instance,  We need to go through the entire  " Data Action Monitor"  to check the Data Action status that we triggered as part of nightly runs. it would be complicated to check the status of each and every DA whether it is failed or successful.

To make this process easier ,

  • The solution involves creating an automated routine through SAC Analytic Apps by utilizing the system models containing the status of the Data Actions .
  • Scheduling the routines at a regular interval so that it monitors the status of DA process and triggers an alert to Admins or the specified SAC users in case of any status other than ‚ÄúSUCCESS‚Äù

Details of the objects used in Implementation

SAP Live System Model    :  PLANNING_DATA_ACTIONS ( Path: Files| System/ Common/ SAC Content/ SAC Content Performance/ SAC Content Performance- Models )

Table_1                                 :     Acts as a source within  the application

Note: 1.This model stores all the data action details in SAC tenant with default time zone :GMT

2. Assuming that we trigger this run this application for every 20 mins through a Calendar publication, so it will send an alert if it finds a failures within the interval

3. Drag all the quired columns to the table considering  " Final Status" as the first row

 

# OnInitialization
var curr_date = new Date(Date.now()); //Get the current Date
console.log(curr_date);

var l_date1 = new Date(Date.now());
var l_date2 = new Date(Date.now());
var min= l_date2.getMinutes();
var hr = l_date2.getHours();
var hr2= hr+4; // Converting the EST hours to GMT
var hr3= hr+4;
var min2 = min-20;// Setting up the mins as per the required interval
// Handling the exceptional case
if(min2<0){
	min2= min + 40;
	hr2= hr2-1;
	console.log(min2);
	console.log(hr2);

	if(hr2<0){
		hr2= 23;
	}
}



l_date2.setMinutes(min2);
l_date2.setHours(hr2);
l_date1.setHours(hr3);
// Setting up the range to filter out the source table
var range = TimeRange.create(TimeRangeGranularity.Minute,l_date2,l_date1);

Table_1.getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("DATETIME_EXECUTE", range);
console.log(range);

var count= 0;
var dims = Table_1.getDimensionsOnRows()[0]; //With assumption that the status column is in the first row
var selections = Table_1.getDataSource().getDataSelections();
var members = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);
// Formatting the table to print in the alert email
var strTable = "--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br> ";
    strTable = "<b>Data Action Name          |   Model Name         |   Process Type                   |   Triggered From              |   Execution Time            |   Status        </b><br>";
strTable = strTable + "--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br> ";
for( var j=0;j<selections.length;j++){
	var member =Table_1.getDataSource().getResultMember(dims,selections[j]);
	{
		members.push(member.description);}}
//console.log(members);
for (var s=0; s<members.length;s++){
	if(members[s]!=="Success"){
		count++;
// Pushing the table details to the format table after filtering out the failed DA details			
	strTable = strTable + "<b>" + count.toString() + ".</b>   "	 + selections[s]["PLANNING_PROCESS_NAME"] + "         |   "+ selections[s]["MODEL_NAME"] +"           |   "+ selections[s]["PLANNING_PROCESS_TYPE"] +"           |   "+ selections[s]["TRIGGERED_FROM_NAME"] +"           |   " + selections[s]["DATETIME_EXECUTE"].substr(0,16) +"        |   " + selections[s]["STATUS_DESC"] +"<br>" ;
	strTable = strTable + "------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br> ";
		
		
	}
}


console.log(count);
if(count>0){
Application.sendNotification({title: "ALERT: SAC Calendar Sequence Failure Notification", 
							  content:"This is a standard notification on your calendar tasks failure (Data Action or Multi-Action). Refer to the list below for the Tasks/Actions that have failed and take appropriate action to resolve the error.<br> <br>"+"Thanks,<br>"+"SAC Monitoring Process <br><br>"+ strTable + "<br>" ,
							  isSendMobileNotification:true,
							  isSendEmail:true,
							
							  receivers:["SAC User1","User2"]});
	
	
}

Since this code is being written on OnInitialization runs through the Calendar publication and send alert emails

Sample Email Alert:

Benefits

  • Business user to be benefitted by reduced lead time for Data action error remediation; automated email-failure notifications to Admins will result in immediate remediation effort
  • Reduced Manual monitoring effort through automation of alert notifications to SAC Admins on Daily/nightly loads.

Conclusion

This automation in SAC reduces manual monitoring, ensures timely intervention.

entry.title: Re: How to connect to onpremise fiori system based on ora...
entry.content:
Hello

There are many tutorial about connecting SAP System to BTP.

You are referring to the FIORI system, so do you want to move the frontend part to BTP only, or do you want to consume system data from BTP services (ECC or S4, for example)?

The basic steps for connecting a SAP system to the BTP cockpit involve using the SAP Cloud Connector. First, connect your SAP BTP cockpit to it and then your SAP system (don't forget to add resources)

On BTP Cockpit, you will then have to create a destination matching the virtual host you defined in SAP CC

Here is a guide (there are many others) https://learning.sap.com/courses/connecting-sap-btp-with-on-premise-via-cloud-connector

 

If you want to focus on Frontend things, then I would recommend exploring the SAP Build Workzone service. But you will also have to connect your SAP System first to your BTP cockpit to consume data

 

Best regards
